questions.prompt: Time shifting x(t) by t₀ affects coefficients by:
questions.explanation: Time shift property: x(t-t₀) has coefficients cₖe^(-jkω₀t₀). Only phase changes—magnitude |cₖ| remains same. This shows time delay equals linear phase shift in frequency domain.

questions.prompt: Differentiation d/dt in time domain corresponds to:
questions.explanation: Differentiation property: if x↔cₖ, then dx/dt↔jkω₀cₖ. Each harmonic is multiplied by jkω₀. This amplifies high frequencies and adds 90° phase shift. Useful for analyzing derivative relationships.

questions.prompt: Integration in time domain corresponds to:
questions.explanation: Integration property: ∫x dt has coefficients cₖ/(jkω₀) for k≠0. Division attenuates high frequencies and shifts phase by -90°. The k=0 case needs special handling (adds to DC).

options: Power in time domain to power in frequency domain
questions.correctAnswer: Power in time domain to power in frequency domain
questions.explanation: Parseval: (1/T)∫|x(t)|²dt = Σ|cₖ|². Average power equals sum of harmonic powers. Energy is conserved between domains. This lets us calculate power without time integration.

questions.prompt: If x(t) is scaled by 2, coefficients become:
questions.explanation: Linearity: 2x(t)↔2cₖ. Scaling the signal scales all coefficients equally. The harmonic structure (relative magnitudes) stays the same, just the overall amplitude changes.
Linearity: adding signals adds their coefficients. x+y↔cₖˣ+cₖʸ. This is superposition: each frequency component adds independently. Foundation for analyzing composite signals.

questions.prompt: Time scaling x(at) changes the fundamental frequency to:
questions.explanation: Time scaling: if x(t) has period T, then x(at) has period T/|a|. Fundamental frequency becomes ω₀' = |a|ω₀. Compressing time expands frequency and vice versa.

questions.prompt: Convolution x(t)*p(t) in time corresponds to _____ of coefficients:
questions.explanation: Convolution property: if x*y, coefficients multiply: cₖ^(x*y) = T·cₖˣ·cₖʸ. This is analogous to the convolution theorem for Fourier transforms. Time convolution = frequency multiplication.

questions.prompt: Multiplication x(t)·y(t) in time corresponds to _____ of coefficients:
questions.explanation: Multiplication in time = convolution of coefficients: cₖ^(xy) = cₖˣ*cₖʸ (discrete convolution). This is the dual of the convolution property. Used in analyzing modulated signals.

questions.prompt: The DC component c₀ after differentiation is:
questions.explanation: Differentiation multiplies by jkω₀. For k=0: j·0·ω₀·c₀ = 0. The DC component vanishes after differentiation, which makes sense: derivative of a constant is zero.
